articles.headline: S.& P. Cuts British Firm’s Debt Rating
articles.snippet: A London money management firm, Cheyne Capital Management, may be forced to liquidate the assets backing its $10 billion commercial paper program in the latest casualty of the jittery credit market.
articles.abstract: A London money management firm, Cheyne Capital Management, may be forced to liquidate the assets backing its $10 billion commercial paper program in the latest casualty of the jittery credit market.
articles.lead_paragraph: A London money management firm, Cheyne Capital Management, may be forced to liquidate the assets backing its $10 billion commercial paper program in the latest casualty of the jittery credit market.

articles.headline: Census Shows a Modest Rise in U.S. Income
articles.snippet: The nation’s median household income grew modestly in 2006 even as the percentage of people without health insurance hit a high.
articles.abstract: The nation’s median household income grew modestly in 2006 even as the percentage of people without health insurance hit a high.
articles.lead_paragraph: The nation’s median household income grew modestly in 2006, the Census Bureau reported yesterday, even as the percentage of people without health insurance hit a high.

articles.headline: NBC Buys TV Group Overseas
articles.snippet: Jeff Zucker, the president and chief executive of NBC, said the deal was the first sign of a strategic shift at the company.
articles.abstract: Jeff Zucker, the president and chief executive of NBC, said the deal was the first sign of a strategic shift at the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: NBC Universal announced yesterday the acquisition of a group of international cable television channels owned by Sparrowhawk Holdings of London, a deal that Jeff Zucker, the president and chief executive of NBC, said was the first sign of a strategic shift at the company.
articles.byline: By Bill Carter and Eric Pfanner

articles.headline: Calls Grow for Foreigners to Have a Say on U.S. Market Rules
articles.snippet: Politicians, regulators and financial specialists outside the United States are seeking a role in the oversight of American markets, banks and rating agencies.
articles.abstract: Politicians, regulators and financial specialists outside the United States are seeking a role in the oversight of American markets, banks and rating agencies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Politicians, regulators and financial specialists outside the United States are seeking a role in the oversight of American markets, banks and rating agencies after recent problems related to subprime mortgages.
articles.byline: By Heather Timmons and Katrin Bennhold

articles.headline: Persistent Fear Drives Stocks Down
articles.snippet: Investors were hit by fresh worries over declining consumer confidence, falling house prices and shrinking profits.
articles.abstract: Investors were hit by fresh worries over declining consumer confidence, falling house prices and shrinking profits.
articles.lead_paragraph: The stock market plunged late in the afternoon yesterday, registering its biggest drop in three weeks as investors were hit by fresh worries over declining consumer confidence, falling house prices, shrinking profits on Wall Street and uncertainty about the Federal Reserve.
articles.byline: By Edmund L. Andrews and Jeremy W. Peters

articles.headline: Wages Up in China as Young Workers Grow Scarce
articles.snippet: Businesses are having a hard time finding able-bodied workers, which could mean higher prices in the U.S.
articles.abstract: Businesses are having a hard time finding able-bodied workers, which could mean higher prices in the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHENZHEN, China, Aug. 28 — At the Dahon bicycle factory here, Zhang Jingming’s fingers move quickly and methodically — grabbing bicycle seats, wrapping them in cardboard and smoothly attaching them to frames.

articles.headline: Turk With Islamic Ties Is Elected President
articles.snippet: Abdullah Gul’s victory breaks an 84-year grip on power by the secular establishment.
articles.abstract: Abdullah Gul’s victory breaks an 84-year grip on power by the secular establishment.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANKARA, Turkey, Aug. 28 — An observant Muslim with a background in Islamic politics was voted in on Tuesday as president, breaking an 84-year grip on power by the secular establishment and ushering a new religious middle class from Turkey’s heartland into the center of the staunchly secular state.
articles.byline: By Sabrina Tavernise and Sebnem Arsu

articles.headline: A Scandal-Scarred G.O.P. Asks, ‘What Next?’
articles.snippet: The sex scandal involving Senator Larry E. Craig of Idaho is the latest challenge to the Republican Party.
articles.abstract: The sex scandal involving Senator Larry E. Craig of Idaho is the latest challenge to the Republican Party.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Aug. 28 — Scott Reed, a Republican strategist, was at a dinner in Philadelphia on Monday night when his cellphone and Internet pager began beeping like crazy. Only later did he learn why. His party was buzzing with news of a sex scandal involving a Republican United States senator — again.

articles.headline: After Stumbling, Mattel Cracks Down in China
articles.snippet: Mattel appears to have become overconfident about its ability to operate in China without major problems.
articles.abstract: Mattel appears to have become overconfident about its ability to operate in China without major problems.
articles.lead_paragraph: EL SEGUNDO, Calif., Aug. 22 — The alarm bell went off for Mattel just as it was preparing to announce that it would recall 1.5 million Chinese-made toys tainted with lead paint.
